patterns: What is the meaning of compound interest?
Tell me about stocks and bonds?

responses.definition: An interest rate is the percentage charged on a loan or paid on savings and investments. It is expressed as an annual percentage rate (APR).
responses.example: If you borrow $1,000 at an interest rate of 5%, you'll pay $50 in interest over a year.

responses.definition: Inflation is the rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services rises, eroding purchasing power over time.
responses.example: If inflation is 2% annually, a $100 item will cost $102 next year.

responses.definition: GDP represents the total value of all goods and services produced in a country over a specific period.
responses.example: A country's GDP grew by 3% this year, meaning its economy expanded by 3%.

responses.definition: Compound interest is the interest calculated on both the initial principal and the accumulated interest from previous periods.
responses.example: If you invest $100 at a 5% annual interest rate, after one year you will have $105. After two years, you will have $110.25.

responses.definition: Stocks are shares of ownership in a company, while bonds are debt securities where you lend money to an entity in exchange for periodic interest payments and the return of principal at maturity.
responses.example: If you buy stocks, you own a small part of a company. If you buy bonds, you're lending money to a company or government.
